educational_objective: Recognize signs of aortic coarctation on a chest radiograph.
question_text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. He is asymptomatic. A systolic murmur is heard in the left infraclavicular region.Blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg in both arms.Chest radiograph is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient most likely has aortic coarctation (Option A), as suggested by the radiographic finding of an indentation at the coarctation site (black arrow), with a “figure 3 sign” caused by concomitant dilatation of the aorta above (blue arrow) and below (red arrow) the area of coarctation. This frontal chest radiograph also demonstrates “notching” of the inferior borders of several ribs (yellow circles). Rib notching is caused by erosion of the rib by forceful pulsations of dilated intercostal arteries involved in collateral blood flow.
